newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkey rejects Dutch Liberals' EU comments.
newsitem.headline: Turkey rejects Dutch Liberals' EU comments.

text.p: Turkey said on Monday that a Dutch political party's rejection of its bid to join the European Union was not compatible with the views of EU governments and modern European civilisation.
Frits Bolkestein, outspoken chief of the conservative Dutch Liberal Party, told a party meeting on Saturday that Turkey did not fit the traditional profile of the 15-member western bloc.

"If what we have seen in the press is true, I do not think that such thoughts and ideas can be considered as compatible with contemporary European civilisation," foreign ministry spokesman Omer Akbel told a news conference.
"Up to now no European government has assumed an identical posture, identical to the ideas that have been attributed to the Liberal Party chairman," Akbel said.

Bolkestein said Turkey, Ukraine and Russia, all potential candidates for EU membership, were too far removed from the bloc's historical traditions -- feudalism, the Renaissance, the Age of Reason and the development of democracy.
"The EU should only offer a place to those countries that share in the great formative events that shaped European history," Bolkestein said.

The Liberal Party, currently the most popular political group in the Netherlands with a general election due in May of next year, is one of three in the right-left ruling coalition. The Netherlands holds the rotating EU presidency until June 30.
Leaders of the EU's Christian Democrat governments, including German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, in February cast serious doubt on Ankara's application for EU membership.
Their comments put further pressure on Turkey-EU relations, already strained by the suspension of financial aid to Ankara under a customs union with the bloc set up last year.
But EU foreign ministers at a meeting in the Dutch town of Apeldoorn last month signalled that Turkey could one day join the Western club.
The foreign ministers of Germany and France have since visited Ankara, where they sought to smooth relations between Turkey and the EU.
